page.title: 12Halstock
page.content: Only the northern part of the village comes within the block. It includes the church and the school, but not the post office nor the pub. As at Pendomer, many of the houses are old - several centuries in some cases - and built mainly of local material, the creamy grey limestone predominating. They are roofed variously with slates, thatch or pantiles. Sometimes the stone is rendered or cement-washed, but the overall effect is greyish. Newer dwellings include some new bungalows in "reconstituted" stone, and a few Victorian or later brick houses, but all blend well into the landscape. Most of the houses are owner-occupied, and vary in size and style; some are detached, some in pairs or short terraces. There are some 20-30 dwellings in Halstock included in this block.
